title: A Durga Puja Pandal In Kolkata Celebrates Gender Diversity With Rainbow Background
text:
“Tumi Dekho Nari Purush, Ami Dekhi Shudhui Manush”

- You see men and women, we only see Humans

This is the theme of one of the Durga Puja pandals in Kolkata. Merging the festive fervour with the celebration of gender diversity and embracing it with open arms, the sight of the pandal is clearly a refreshing one.

The pandal with an LGBTQ+ theme is conceptualised by Dum Dum Tarun Dal.

Facebook/Yes We Exist

Interestingly, their Durga idol is a mix of Krishna and Durga.

The social shunning and continuing marginalisation of the third gender was the highlight of this pandal.

There was a reference to ascetic Chaitanya Mahaprabhu''s love for lord Krishna, and the various taboos on the third gender. In the imagination of the artist, the hand of restriction is transformed into birds. The pavilion also had huge masks, symbolising the LGBTQ community's vulnerability, which forces them to hide their true identity out of fear of lack of social acceptance.

Of late, mainstream religious groups are doing their part to embrace gender diversity.

Last month, during a Ganesh Chaturthi procession in Mumbai, a Ganesha idol has an LGBTQ+ flag as the background, with people dancing around it.

Indians have come a long way in accepting the LGBTQ+ community as a part of our society. The same is now reflected in mainstream festivals too.
